basics.name: Alejandro Gomez Espinosa
basics.label: Experimental Particle Physicist
basics.summary: Ecuadorian, experimental particle physicist, currently working for Carnegie Mellon University at the CMS Experiment at CERN. My area of expertise is in particles decaying hadronically. I am interested in searches with jets and di-Higgs searches. I am also interested in workflow orchestration and continuous integration tools.

work.name: Carnegie Mellon University
work.summary: Studying the self-interaction of the Higgs boson in the di-Higgs production channel. Research focuses on the four b-quark decay channel and is expanding to improve current studies in the bbWW channel. Additionally, working on workflow orchestration tools and analysis reproducibility. Advocating for the adoption of modern programming practices, including continuous integration (CI), extensive use of unit tests, and regular result replication using Snakemake and REANA

work.name: Institute for Particle and Astrophysics, ETH-Zurich
work.summary: Lead the measurements for the ttH production in the H(bb) channel using Run II data from CMS, particularly in the boosted regime. Additionally leading the measurements of jet substructure observables in different high transverse momentum jet environments. Moreover, I have significant contributions in commissioning and calibration of boosted taggers for heavy resonances and pileup mitigation techniques at high trigger level for Run III

publications.name: Zur Elektrody/namik bewegter Körper
publications.summary: It concerned an interpretation of the Michelson–Morley experiment and the properties of light and time. Special relativity incorporates the principle that the speed of light is the same for all inertial observers regardless of the state of motion of the source.

publications.name: Über einen die Erzeugung und Verwandlung des Lichtes betreffenden heuristischen Gesichtspunkt
publications.summary: In the second paper, he applied the quantum theory to light to explain the photoelectric effect. In particular, he used the idea of light quanta (photons) to explain experimental results, but stressed the importance of the experimental results. The importance of his work on the photoelectric effect earned him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921.

publications.name: Die Grundlage der allgemeinen Relativitätstheorie
publications.summary: The publication of the theory of general relativity made him internationally famous. He was professor of physics at the universities of Zurich (1909–1911) and Prague (1911–1912), before he returned to ETH Zurich (1912–1914).

projects.name: Quantum Computing
projects.summary: Quantum computing is the use of quantum-mechanical phenomena such as superposition and entanglement to perform computation. Computers that perform quantum computations are known as quantum computers.
